abstract: ESPN dominates sports on television. Now, the cable heavyweight is making a run at the big screen.
snippet: ESPN dominates sports on television. Now, the cable heavyweight is making a run at the big screen.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  ESPN dominates sports on television. Now, the cable heavyweight is making a run at the big screen.

headline.main: With Partners, ESPN Is Expanding in Filmmaking
headline.print_headline: With Partners, ESPN Is Expanding in Filmmaking

abstract: Among the Hollywood developers scrambling to create original Internet programs, Michael Eisner is one of the very few who can claim early success.
snippet: Among the Hollywood developers scrambling to create original Internet programs, Michael Eisner is one of the very few who can claim early success.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  When Michael D. Eisner left the Walt Disney Company in 2005 and set about remaking himself in new media, investing in a video-sharing Web site and starting a digital studio, some people in Hollywood snickered. Here we go, the whispers went, another fading star who doesn’t know when to leave the stage.

headline.main: The Very Model of a Modern Media Mogul
headline.print_headline: The Very Model of a Modern Media Mogul

Here we go, the whispers went, another fading star who doesn’t know when to leave the stage.
lead_paragraph: When Michael D. Eisner left the Walt Disney Company in 2005 and set about remaking himself in new media, investing in a video-sharing Web site and starting a digital studio, some people in Hollywood snickered. Here we go, the whispers went, another fading star who doesn’t know when to leave the stage.

abstract: ESPN, which dominates sports on television, is collaborating with Creative Artists Agency and Walt Disney Studios to produce and distribute theatrical films, Brooks Barnes reports in Monday’s New York Times. The network “is also hiring 30 filmmakers to produce one-hour mini-movies to appear on the channel starting in September 2009.”
lead_paragraph: ESPN, which dominates sports on television, is collaborating with Creative Artists Agency and Walt Disney Studios to produce and distribute theatrical films, Brooks Barnes reports in Monday’s New York Times. The network “is also hiring 30 filmmakers to produce one-hour mini-movies to appear on the channel starting in September 2009.”
